facts.text: Writ Petition No. 211 of 1963 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental rights under Articles 14, 16 and 19.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 211 of 1963. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of the Fundamental Rights. K. Garg, for the petitioner. K. Daphtary, Attorney-General, B. R. L. Iyengar and R. G. K. Achar, for the respondents.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 31, 1964 by SIKRI, J.

anchor.surface_text: March 31, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SIKRI, J.-This is a petition under Art. 32 of the Consti- tution for enforcing the fundamental rights of the petitioner under Arts. 14, 16 and 19 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Petitioner selected by Madras Public Service Commission as Lower Division Clerk under Madras Ministerial Service Rules in 1949, allotted to Revenue Department, posted in South Kanara District.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was selected by the Madras Public Service Commission as a Lower Division Clerk under the Madras Ministerial Service Rules in 1949, and was allotted to the Revenue Department and posted in South Kanara District. He was promoted as Upper Division Clerk on April 2, 1956.

facts.text: Petitioner promoted as Upper Division Clerk on April 2, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: He was promoted as Upper Division Clerk on April 2, 1956. According to the petitioner, he should have been promoted much earlier as he had rendered outstanding and meritorious service.

facts.text: Petitioner claims he should have been promoted much earlier than April 2, 1956 due to outstanding and meritorious service.

anchor.surface_text: According to the petitioner, he should have been promoted much earlier as he had rendered outstanding and meritorious service. According to the State, the petitioner was companysidered for inclusion in the eligibility list from 1955 onwards, but was number selected as he was number companysidered fit.

facts.text: State claims petitioner considered for eligibility list from 1955 onwards but not selected as not considered fit.

anchor.surface_text: According to the State, the petitioner was companysidered for inclusion in the eligibility list from 1955 onwards, but was number selected as he was number companysidered fit. The State admits that he was promoted as Upper Division Clerk with effect from April 2, 1956, but alleges that this was on a temporary basis.

facts.text: State admits petitioner promoted as Upper Division Clerk with effect from April 2, 1956 on temporary basis, later reverted and then posted as temporary Upper Division Clerk.

anchor.surface_text: The State admits that he was promoted as Upper Division Clerk with effect from April 2, 1956, but alleges that this was on a temporary basis. He was later reverted and then again posted as a temporary Upper Division Clerk.

facts.text: In August 1957, petitioner considered and included in eligibility list at Serial No. 14.

anchor.surface_text: In August 1957, the petitioner was companysidered and included in the eligibility list at Serial No. 14. This list was regularised on December 12, 1957, in accordance with Rules 39 e  and 35 of the Madras State and Subordinate Service Rules, with effect from October 19, 1957.

facts.text: Eligibility list regularised on December 12, 1957 with effect from October 19, 1957 in accordance with Rules 39(e) and 35 of Madras State and Subordinate Service Rules.

anchor.surface_text: This list was regularised on December 12, 1957, in accordance with Rules 39 e  and 35 of the Madras State and Subordinate Service Rules, with effect from October 19, 1957. According to the petitioner this resulted in the loss of benefit of service and increments.

facts.text: Petitioner claims regularization resulted in loss of benefit of service and increments.

anchor.surface_text: According to the petitioner this resulted in the loss of benefit of service and increments. In the meantime, reorganisation of States took place under the State Reorganisation Act  XXXVII of 1956  South Kanara District, except Kasaragod Taluk, went to the new Mysore State and the petitioner was allotted to it.

facts.text: Reorganisation of States under State Reorganisation Act, 1956; South Kanara District except Kasaragod Taluk went to new Mysore State; petitioner allotted to it.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, reorganisation of States took place under the State Reorganisation Act  XXXVII of 1956  South Kanara District, except Kasaragod Taluk, went to the new Mysore State and the petitioner was allotted to it.

facts.text: Appointed day under State Reorganisation Act is November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: prior to, November 1, 1956, by various orders, reduced the petitioner in rank in violation of Art. 311 2  of the Constitution and Art. 16. ... the companyditions of service applicable immediately before the appointed day to the case of any person referred to in sub-section  1  of subsection  2  shall number be varied to his disadvantage except with the previous approval of the Central Government.

facts.text: Government of India memorandum No. O. SRDI-1. APM-57 dated May 11, 1957 to all State Governments regarding conditions of service post-reorganisation.

anchor.surface_text: On May 11, 1957, the Government of India addressed a memorandum  No. O. SRDI-1. APM-57  to all State Governments. Broadly speaking, the Central Government said that some companyditions of service should be protected, e.g., substantive pay of permanent employees, certain type of special pay, lave rules unless the Government servant opts for new leave rules, etc.

facts.text: Central Government memorandum stated no protection needed for departmental promotion rules post-reorganisation.

anchor.surface_text: But in respect of departmental promotion it said that the question whether any protection should be given in respect of rules and companyditions applicable to Government servants affected by reorganisation immediately before the date of reorganisation in the matter of travelling allowance, discipline, companytrol, classification, appeal, companyduct, pro- bation and departmental promotion was also companysidered.

facts.text: Mysore General Services Revenue Subordinate Branch Recruitment Rules, 1959 made without previous approval of Central Government under s.115(7) of State Reorganisation Act - petitioner's claim.

anchor.surface_text: The two points may be formulated as follows That the Mysore General Services  Revenue Subordinate Branch  Recruitment Rules, 1959, were number made with the previous approval of the Central Government under s. 115 7  of the State Re-organisation Act, and, therefore, do number govern the petitioner insofar as the companyditions of service have been varied to his disadvantage

facts.text: Petitioner is a person referred to in sub-sections 1 and 2 of s.115 of State Reorganisation Act - undisputed.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the petitioner is one of those persons.

facts.text: Petitioner claims Madras Government reduced him in rank prior to November 1, 1956 in violation of Art. 311(2) and Art. 16.

anchor.surface_text: That the Madras-Government had, prior to, November 1, 1956, by various orders, reduced the petitioner in rank in violation of Art. 311 2  of the Constitution and Art. 16.

facts.text: State of Madras not made a party to the petition.

anchor.surface_text: Firstly, the State of Madras has number been made a party to this petition.

facts.text: Petitioner never raised claims of rank reduction while serving under State of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, he never raised these points while he was serving under the State of Madras.

facts.text: State asserts all orders complained against were passed by competent authorities after considering merits of petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: The State in its reply has asserted that all the orders companyplained against were passed by companypetent authorities, after companysidering the merits of the petitioner on each occasion.

facts.text: Court holds Mysore Recruitment Rules, 1959 validly made with previous approval via the 1957 memorandum.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this amounted to previous approval within the proviso to s. 115 7 . It may be mentioned that by this memorandum the State Governments were required to send companyies of all new rules to the Central Government for its information. Therefore in our opinion, there is numberforce in the first companytention of the learned companynsel for the petitioner, and we hold that the ruler, were validly made.

facts.text: Court finds no infringement of Article 16 established.

anchor.surface_text: We find numberforce in this companytention and hold that numberinfringement of Art. 16 has been established.

facts.text: Petition fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, in the result, the petition fails.

anchor.surface_text: There are two preliminary hurdles in the way of the petitioner regarding the second point taken on his behalf. Firstly, the State of Madras has number been made a party to this petition. Secondly, he never raised these points while he was serving under the State of Madras.
We find numberforce in this companytention and hold that numberinfringement of Art. 16 has been established.

holdings.text: the expression 'previous approval' in the proviso to s. 115(7) would include a general approval to the variation in the conditions of service within certain limits, indicated by the Union Government

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, in the setting in which the proviso to s. 115 7  is placed, the expression previous approval would include a general approval to the variation in the companyditions of service within certain limits, indicated by the Union Government. It has to be remembered that Art. 309 of the Constitution gives, subject to the provisions of the Constitution, full powers to a State Government to make rules. The proviso to s. 115 7  limits that power, but that limitation is removable by the Central Government by giving its previous approval. In this companytext, we think that it companyld number have been the intention of Parliament that Service Rules made by States would be scrutinised in the minutest detail by the Central Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Considering context of Art. 309 power to make rules, practicalities of state variations, and broad purpose of proviso to ensure prior concurrence without requiring detailed scrutiny of each rule

holdings.text: the Central Government memorandum of May 11, 1957 amounted to previous approval within the proviso to s. 115(7)

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this amounted to previous approval within the proviso to s. 115 7 . It may be mentioned that by this memorandum the State Governments were required to send companyies of all new rules to the Central Government for its information.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Memorandum explicitly permitted states to vary conditions like departmental promotion without protection, and required sending copies of new rules for information

holdings.text: the Mysore General Services Revenue Subordinate Branch Recruitment Rules, 1959, were validly made and govern the petitioner

anchor.surface_text: Therefore in our opinion, there is numberforce in the first companytention of the learned companynsel for the petitioner, and we hold that the ruler, were validly made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Previous approval obtained via 1957 memorandum allowing variation in relevant service conditions

holdings.text: no infringement of Art. 16 has been established

anchor.surface_text: It was for the companypetent authorities to judge the merits of the petitioner. We find numberforce in this companytention and hold that numberinfringement of Art. 16 has been established.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State of Madras not party; claims not raised earlier under Madras; all orders by competent authorities after considering merits; no evidence of discrimination shown

anchor.surface_text: In re Bosworth and Corporation of Gravesend 1 , but this, decision has numberbearing on the point under discussion. Permission was sought of the Secre- tary of State to add additional land to an existing cemetery  1  19051  2 K.B. 426.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, in the setting in which the proviso to s. 115 7  is placed, the expression previous approval would include a general approval to the variation in the companyditions of service within certain limits, indicated by the Union Government. It has to be remembered that Art. 309 of the Constitution gives, subject to the provisions of the Constitution, full powers to a State Government to make rules. The proviso to s. 115 7  limits that power, but that limitation is removable by the Central Government by giving its previous approval. In this companytext, we think that it companyld number have been the intention of Parliament that Service Rules made by States would be scrutinised in the minutest detail by the Central Government.
Accordingly, in the result, the petition fails.
Accordingly, in the result, the petition fails.
